div3.head: The Anti-substitute law.
div3.p:
The passage of the bill terminating the privilege of employing substitutes for the army, by such overwhelming majorities in both branches of Congress, may be accepted as a clear and positive expression of the sentiment of the people and the army on the subject.
That it will operate harshly in individual cases, there cannot be a doubt; but it is very likely that these cases are only exceptions to the general fact that the practices of substitution, through the villainies of agents and the unscrupulousness of persons hiring themselves to fight for others, have been one vast fraud upon the Government and the country.
The whole country was satisfied of this fact, and the whole country demanded a thorough measure abolishing the system.
With a knowledge of the outrages perpetrated under it, its demoralizing effects at home, and the discontent and murmuring it occasioned in camp, people will not likely deplore the partial injustice inflicted by its overthrow.
They will consider it as a public necessity and public benefit — necessary for the replenishing of the army and a blessing, as it lops off one of the heads of the muenster of national abuses which has thrown such serious obstacles in the way of the Government and the army in the great struggle now pending, that is to decide the fate of this Confederacy of States--whether it is to be tributary or independent, bond or free.

The passage of the law will produce not only much excitement among the class who have availed themselves of the privilege of substitution, but it will cause a stampede amongst the less loyal of them — nay, it is known that this stampede has already begun.
We have no apprehension of detriment to the people of the South from this.
The flying multitude that will depart hence to escape service can better be spared than not. They will most assuredly "leave their country for their country's good." With them the Southern Confederacy is of no value save as a place to make money by extortion and fraud — by monopolizing articles of commerce and forcing the people to pay monstrous prices for them.
In return, the Confederacy derives from them nothing but evil.
They would use the Confederacy to amass wealth, while they feel none of the obligations of a citizen, and use every trick and contrivance to avoid serving that country which affords them asylum and protection.
They may, it is true, be captured and put into Lincoln's army; but even then it is better for us. It is better to fight a traitor than to have him in our own ranks to bring about disaster by his treachery.

div3.head: The Creole population of the South.
div3.p:
The word Creolesignifies, we believe, native.
In Louisiana and Mississippi every person born in the State is called a Louisiana or Mississippi Creole.
Nothing is more common in the former of these States than to hear of "Creole Frenchmen," as distinguished from Frenchmen from France.
In the same way they speak of Creole horses, Creole cattle, Creole sheep, &c. Out of Louisiana and Mississippi, however, the term seems to have a more limited significance, and a Creole is understood to be a person that has mixed African and European blood in his veins — precisely the same description of person, Indeed, with what is called a quadroon in New Orleans.
In this sense it seems to be taken by Mr. Dargan, of Alabama, in the very important bill which he has introduced into the House of Representatives, and which is now before the Committee on Military Affairs.
The object of the bill is to receive into the Confederate service all that portion of the population of Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and Florida, known as Creoles.

We have no means of estimating the number of men that the passage of this bill would place in the service of the Confederate States.
We should suppose, however, that it would not fall short of 20,000.
A large proportion of these persons are as white as anybody, having but a very small portion of African blood in their veins.--Many of them have large estates and own large numbers of slaves.
Formerly — so far as regards Louisiana, at least — they were forbidden by law to intermarry with whites; but that law, we believe, has been repealed, and an enabling act passed in its stead.
The better portion of them are a highly respectable class of people, and all of them, almost without exception, are warm Southern men, and eagerly desirous to bear arms in defence of the South.
We learn from Gen. Dargan's speech that on a former occasion they applied through him to Gen. Randolph, at that time Secretary of War, for leave to enter the service.
The application was rejected on the ground that it would afford a pretext to the enemy for arming our negroes.
This objection, substantial enough at the time, has been obviated by the course of the enemy, who has already armed fifty thousand Southern slaves, and will arm all of them if he can. Application has since been made to the present Secretary, who rejects it because, says he,"the position we occupy before the world would be damaged thereby."

Before rejecting a bill which tends so materially to strengthen our muster list, we think it would be just as well to understand what is our "position before the world,"and as the Secretary seems to understand it better than anybody else, we hope he will enlighten us. To our simple apprehension it appears that "the world" assigns us no position at all. We are ignoredby every power on the face of the earth, from England, France, and Russia, down to the dirtiest little tyrant whose five-acre patch of a kingdom is watered by the Elbe, the Oder, or the Wester.
Our ships are scarcely allowed to touch at their ports, our representatives at their courts are insulted in every conceivable manner, we are universally styled the "so-called" Confederate States whenever it is necessary to speak of us at all in a public document, and in the Queen of England's speech this war is designated as "the civil war now raging in the United States." --Really, we should be obliged for any information as to that "position" whose requirements are so exacting as to deprive us of the services of twenty thousand brave soldiers at such a time as this.

div3.head: Southern Literary Messenger.
div3.p:
This old and valued magazine, which has outlived all its kindred enterprises in the South, has been purchased by Messrs. Alfriend and Wedderburn, and will in future be conducted in their name.
There can be no doubt that it will be conducted with spirit and talent, and we bespeak for it the largest share of patronage.
It has always borne a high reputation for talent, and has always been genuinely Southern in its teachings.
In character it will undergo no alteration, or only just so much as may imply a fresh supply of energy and enterprise infused into it by young and enthusiastic proprietors.

div4.p: At the residence of her husband, near this city, on Tuesday evening, December 29th, at half- past 3 o'clock, of consumption, Mrs. Harriet A, wife of Mr. James Templeman.
Her funeral will take place from Centenary Church this (Thursday) morning, at 11 o'clock. --The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend.

In this city, on the 26th inst, of pneumonia.
Willie Hellings, infant son of P N and H E Jewett, aged 6 months and 23 days.

lg.l: Oh, thou blest infant, divinely blest,
Thou hast ascended to thy heavenly rest;
Thou hast risen from this world of woe,
To those bright realms of bliss, where sin can never go.
Dearest Willie, thou hast left us,
Here thy loss we deeply feel;
But'tis God who hath bereft us,
He can all our sorrows heal.

div4.head: Obituary.
div4.p: Died, on Friday night, December 11th, 1863, in this city, Mr. George S Barnes, only son of William C and Lydia Barnes, aged 18 years and 5 months.

This young friend, whose death we have been called to mourn, fell a victim to a disease which has hurried so many in the prime of life to the tomb, typhoid pneumonia.
His illness, which continued several weeks, was quite severe, and his being delicate the ravages of the fever soon began to show its terrible effect, and defied the constant efforts to arrest it on the part of his affectionate mother, who nursed him day and night until death took their suffering child from the parents who loved him as only father and mother can love.--These fond parents feel deeply the loss of him who by his obedience had endeared himself not only to them, but to many friends who knew him. We mourn, also, that one so promising should in the spring of life be cut down, and that the bright house of his parents should so soon be overshadowed.

The parents of our young friend have drank deeply of the cup of sorrow, for whilst residing in Norfolk during the yellow fever they lost two very interesting children.
Besides the death of these two there occurred also at the same time the death of a mother and brother of Mr. W C Barnes.
Out of a family of seven six laid sick of the fever, four died.
Mrs Barnes did not contract this fever, and after the recovery of her husband and son the three remaining members — father, mother and son — moved to this city.
Though coming as strangers they soon found many friends, all of whom sympathize with these parents in the great loss which they have sustained, May the good Shepherd gather these sorrowing parents into his fold when this life, with all its troubles and sorrows, shall have been ended.
May they find in Heaven that union which knows no separation, is the prayer of the writer of this feeble tribute to the memory of our departed friend.

lg.l: Tho' we hope soon to meet them
And to five here without them
They are gone, and we never
Where we live but to part
That are bound to the heart.
But we hope, tho' we weep,
We shall meet them in Heaven.

div3.head: 500 dollars reward.
div3.p: --Ran away from the subscriber on Tuesday morning, two negro women and a child.

Martha is black, 22 years of age, and has as ugly scar or bald place on the top and back of her head.
Her child is a boy three and a half years old, and black.
Sarah is a stout woman, of gingerbread color, 22 years old, and will probably weigh 150 pounds.
I will pay the above reward for the return of the three negroes to me, or $250 for Sarah, and the same amount for Martha and child.

div3.head: One Hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran off front Richard Moore's, on the Meadow Bridge about six weeks ago, a negro boy named Alonzo — goes by the name of Lonney.
He is about 18 years old, very black, and has an old look for his age. about five feet high, and has been selling in the Market for the past five or six years. I will give above reward for his delivery to me or confinement so that I get him.
div3.closer:
James Moore.
No. 8 Franklin st. de 31--2t

div3.head: Three Hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaways from the undersigned on Saturday night last my negro woman Martha and her child Nannie.--Martha is of a dark complexion, about 28 years old, and generally dresses in black.
Nannie is a bright mulatto, about 12 years old. I have every reason to believe that the above negroes are trying to make their way to the enemy, as they left without any cause whatever, and took all of their clothes off with them.
I will give the above reward for the arrest and delivery to me of the above named negroes, or $150 for either one of them, or if they lodged in any jail in this city so that I can get them.

closer.signed: R. B. Tyler, C. S. Laboratory.

div3.head: 200 dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Will be paid for the apprehension of Hannah, who ran away from the service of G V Case, of Richmond, Dec. 23 Said servant is of gingerbread color; upper teeth on in front; about 5 feet 10 inches high, and about 20 or 30 years old. She had on an old plaid dress and a red and green shawl.
She is supposed to be making her way to Mathews county or the Yankee lines Information to be left with J B Davis, at Hill, Dickinson &Co's, Franklin st.

div3.head: Fifty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Fifty dollars reward offered for the apprehension of my man Peter who worked on the furcations near Richmond, and on the day the bands took the cars for Lynchburg he was missing.
He is a copper-colored negro six feet high, was raised in Nansemond county, has a wife there.
For his safe delivery in any or to Tyler &Son, Richmond, I will pay the above reward.

div3.head: 50 dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway, about seven weeks ago, a negro man named Irvine.
vine is about 25 years old, of dark gingerbread color about 5 feet 9 inches high, heavily built, and round shouldered.
He wears a long drab sack coat, steamers if confused, and probably has hired himself Richmond.
The above reward will be paid on delivery to Lee &James, Richmond.
